comments.commentBody: So you agree with his policy but you're taken aback by the way he expresses himself? I assume your idea of a chief executive is a well-programmed computer that has all the facts and figures at its disposal and is able to spit them out in the form of comprehensible charts and graphs. The rest of us are satisfied with imperfect members of our own species.
I often forget to buy herbs, so have tried growing as many as possible. I'm using a lot more thyme now that there's a spreading patch in one "flower" bed.
"It's an expensive and wasteful habit"....But this is not about guidelines to reduce expense and waste it is about diet. What makes protein a bad diet for men and boys?

I went to the site and examined the rankings. It *looks* like an honest effort, but seems to actually measure "Washington DC Insiderness" instead of bipartisanship(buypartisanship). Sanders does not deserve such a low score. The metrics leave a lot to be desired.

Then, again, Senator Lugar was "primaried" by his own party, and lost his seat! Could that explain the disdain for noncentrist political leanings?

Why are you surprised? Trump puts on a very good show. He's like the right wing talk radio host-in-chief. He voices the frustration that people have with other people. He has a comedian's timing and vocabulary. He's right – the other Republican candidates ARE stiffs.

He calls out Hillary for her corporate contributions in language that everyone can understand, in a monologue constructed in the same fashion as a skilled stand-up - complaining about industry sending factories out of the country.

I fail to see how Hilary Clinton can be criticized for her dealings with Wall Street. It's like dealing with the mafia in New York City real estate -  love'em or hate'em you get nowhere unless you deal with-em. No deal - no dice is the situation.
MTF, I like Godiva chocolate, mainly as Christmas gifts for secretaries (aka assistants).

"Protein that is not utilized by the body is turned into glucose by the liver"....I get that some protein can eventually be broken down by the liver to glucose, but to compare it as an equivalent to carbohydrates (which is polymeric sugar units) is a pretty far reach.

and Elke
After yesterday's puzzle, had to think inside the box.
Possible theme (on Fri.)? The DREAMGIRLS from the NW found their way via MOVES to the BREAKDANCE of the JERSEY BOYS in the SW. That's it.
Really had to STARE at SHORT O , even though COSMO was closer than "plot".
Some possibly gore : with TOOK A STAB and LACERATED, I suspect more than a COTTON SWAB will be needed for ABSORPTION.

On a more pleasant picture, ERNO Laszlo's products (?available at MACY's ?) are great for ANOINTINGS.

Hey, I DID MY BEST, but it is Friday, and the LETTER TRAY is full with some bills that we still GET in the mail .

and Elke
Correction: the JERSEY BOYS are in the SE (not SW).
After yesterday's puzzle, anything is better. (Sorry)

.
Bills come in the mail?

Not "the post"?

Yesterday was a chore; today is a puzzle.

The fundamental flaw in the logic of this article, and the reason so many Nobel-level economists have been wrong in their predictions over the past decade...

...is that there is really no such thing as a "stand alone national economy" any more.

Most economic models are based on "nodes" of "national economies" with thin links of "trade" between those nodes. This article assumes that the US "node" has some extraordinary power vis-a-vis all the other national nodes on Earth.

The reality is that supra-node physical trade, and free-flowing finance among 100+ country nodes is now the dominant force of a unified global economy, and the national nodes have relatively little influence.

The Chinese stock markets are flipping around, but China still has the largest single physical production engine on Earth, and it has more than 150,000,000 expat citizens who either control or influence more than 50% of the physical commodities on Earth - and can ship them anywhere on short notice.

India has the largest and most diverse commercial democracy on Earth and can use barter, not government controlled currency to absorb economic shocks.

7 billion mobile phones, with 90% per capital penetration in the poorest regions of Earth, transmit more than $400 billion of "remittances" among guest workers of the world.

The "Tinkertoy" economic models of the 20th Century are now as obsolete as the land line telephone.

And traditional economists are been left behind by waves of human connectivity.

And capitalism as it exists now - based on 17-20th century models of growth (and greed) at any costs and an insufficient acknowledgement of the so-called planetary externalities (and usually too little too late) - will be left behind by rising waves of oceans and environmental catastrophes that will beset the planet.  It is the single most pressing issue for this connected younger generation.
Can I still make this cake if I don't have a food processor?  I do have a Nutribullet. Would that work?
If you have something that will turn the walnuts to powder, it seems to me that the cake can be made by a simple sponge cake procedure.
I could use a coffee grinder to pulverize the walnuts and sugar, but I don't know what a simple sponge cake recipe is.....
I think using a stand-mixer or hand mixer would work just fine.
Hokay, Mister Crabby - please to be divulging which recipes from the All About Braising you are preferring? Already, I am thanking you.

Why did everyone believe that the Chinese Communist Party could manage the Chinese economy, Stock Market,  and the large number of State Owned Enterprises, using cronyism, and corruption and avoid a financial crisis? the majority of loans for chinese SOEs and real estate are bad. Now the Chinese elite are taking the money and immigrating. Watch out because that hot chinese  money is invested in  the US stock markets, too

Of course such an event will have some emotional influence on other markets. But not a real effect as in if the valuation of an American company is x then it is still x unless it has a lot of exposure to China. Which mostly is not the case. Also China market is a somewhat young immature market. After our own crash investors are a bit more resilient now and will not panic and sell as easily. It will smooth out as the Chinese Financial people are doing the right thing to stabilize it sanely and pragmatically. Still some volatility like a storm it water and when the winds die down the water will calm. Now is a buying opportunity with possible some more in the future based on financial analysis of the stocks and not some mumbo jumbo political this and that nonsense. Take the long view to make decisions now.

Stock market trading halt again is a small indicator of a larger problem. Fear, greed, inflated prices, corrupt system, political manipulations and social mobility issues are all factors contributing to stock market collapse and economic disasters. Fed reserve is printing more money than it should have since 1930's. Chinese are following the same Market Economy Principals, the traders not the political junta, to make more money in the shortest possible time.

Chinese people's ambitions are more real and challenged by population pressure, history, competition, greed and social mobility. Fear has no limit, greed has no end, regulations and their implementation at global level may determine different results in events of crashes. Ripple effects would reduce people's savings in US to nothing, a painful reality, unfolding gradually. Lawmakers in USA have to work on Campaign funding rules to minimize lobbyists influence in engineering disastrous decisions, policies and their outcome. Or the supreme court can take affirmative action in curtailing political corruption to make lawmakers accountable for not acting in the best interest of their people and country.

Chinese corruption, greed and power struggle in society would manifest in stick market debacles and send more shock waves to US and rest of the world. To minimize the effects, US have to put its house in order, the Congress and Senate should legislate what's needed, not what a few interest groups want.
The oligarchs use their inside info to buy low and sell high leaving the middle class worker bees, who have been trained to dollar cost average, holding the bag.
CCP vs. The Invisible Hand, who will come out on top?

Hello NYChap,
Although this lists me as coming from Tianjin, China, I am a retired American from LA Calif. At the end of your posting, you raise the question about whether or not the Wall Street Gang is doing it's job, paying attention. I think that unfortunately, they are doing their job, which entails most of all making huge sums of money for their rich and elite clients. In the process they make obscene amounts of money for themselves. They don't care about the small fry kind of people such as yourself and my mother, who lives a lot on the investments she and my dad made to live on in their retirement (golden years). My dad died from cancer in June 2014, and I worry about my mom and her supporting herself at 85 yrs of age. This of course is of no concern for the greedy, money grubbiing, bottom feeders that make up this self centered financial world nowadays. I long for the time when a man's word was the most important thing, his passport in life.
The people who work for the Fed do not have the resources or inside information that the Gordon Geckos of the world do. They can't protect us.

It is not just China, but also the troubles ahead in U.S. The Wall Street market bubble grow with U.S government pumping money into it. Now, the bubble suppose to continue to grow from employed people pumping money into it. The problem is with wage stagnation and low paying jobs people unable to pump more money for the bubble to grow. Banks are back to their old habits.The Chinese has manufacturing bubble. They kept manufacturing goods thinking there is an ever ending export market. Having realized that is a mirage, they are trying to develop domestic market. The problem is they kept wages artificially low, so people don't have money, which is complicating the development of domestic market. The bottom line is that U.S lost the middle class while China never had it.
So, an economy controlled by a central government with unfettered power and uncontrolled corruption does not in the longer term work.  Surprise! Surprise!

At least your retirement "stool" has all three legs.

Most of us do not have, and have no hope of ever having, defined-benefit pensions.

I do not begrudge you yours. Not at all! I just wish the rest of us had such, too.

Imagine the effects of the stock market chicanery on the pensionless majority of us.

Pardon my ignorance but I am wondering if China's downward spiral is the reason for the so-called fast-track for the Pacific trading pact? In other words the multi-national (or I should say "no-national") corporations are looking for the new slave labor in the area.

We need tariffs that bring manufacturing home here to the U.S. so that we can maintain our way of life. I don't mind if I pay $10 more for an i-phone, do you? Or perhaps, the shareholders could bear $10 less in dividends per year.
@PK Exactly! And its high time more people realized that.

There have been reports for a while. The Chinese saw a global economic crash and manipulated their currency to enable numerous,  huge purchases at rock bottom prices. Building cities out of pure speculation,  with few residents - mostly those whose land was confiscated by the government.  I  suspect that is why they eliminated the one child law. They need consumers and tax payers. China is corrupt.

This is an out of control, corrupt, autocratic basically Communist regime rotten to its core. Their economy is teetering on the edge of a precipice due to the house of cards nature of its business ethic .
Beware.
